children.text:
At the beginning of this video, the old woman claims that the ICE officers
would not "get to scare folks on [her] block" while she is around. (TODO: add citation) Here we
can infer that the old woman and the others on the block are all stakeholders
in this situation. The audience would like know from current events that the
ICE officers plan to arrest those who were deemed to have been in the country
illegally, so they could conclude that the freedom of the old woman and of
others who live on that block would be on the line. The old woman also presents
herself as a heroic figure by claiming to be the force that prevents the ICE
officers from harming those who live on the block. This heroic presentation can
be seen as an appeal to ethos as the audience is more apt to see the woman in a
positive light since she is trying to protect those who are vulnerable.

At this point in the video, the officers are responding to the old woman's claim
that they are acting unjustly by claiming that they are performing a "lawful"
investigation. (TODO: add citation) This is an attempt at appealing logos since they are giving a
particular reason for their actions. Their job as officers is to investigate
and handle violations of the law and they are claiming that their actions as
depicted in this video align with that job. The fact that the officers are
claiming to do their job also gives them a stake in this video as if they
fail to do their job properly, it can be concluded that they stand the risk
of losing it.

At this point in the video, the old woman being depicted questions the
lawfulness of the ICE officers' actions in this video, noting that they "don't
even have a warrant with a judge's name on it" (TODO: add citation). This
information damages the credibility of the ICE officers since they seem to be
acting outside the law while claiming that they are acting within the law. There
is also an element of logos in her statement since the old woman is responding
to the counterargument that presented by the officers that they are conducting
a "lawful investigation" (TODO: add citation) by giving an example of a law
that they are violating in their investigating, that being performing the
investigation without a warrant.

In this interval, the old woman says that "[she] knows her rights [and] so does
everyone watching" (TODO: add citation). In this statement, there is both ethos
and pathos at play here. For ethos, the old woman claims to have knowledge of
the rights that the laws of the United States gives her, so the audience is
more inclined to trust her conclusion due to her being informed of the topic of
this situation. For pathos, the old woman's statement appeals to the audience
in the way that she claims that they also are familiar with the topic at hand,
which presents the evidence that she uses in her argument (officers requiring
a warrant to perform an investigation) as common knowledge. Therefore, the
audience would be more likely to side with the woman in this video because of
that common knowledge.
